body:
@lukasreschke which bugs are you referring to that happen with sqlite? i only know the databade locking migration problems that can/show be fixed by us. totally possible.
what other problems does sqlie has? the performance is not as good as other databases if you have a lof of users but good enough for smaller installations. so a warning here should be sufficient. 
i'm not sure about this change. the right way to do in my opinion is to fix the migration with sqlie instead of creating the impression that they need mysql to run owncloud.
what do you think @jancborchardt ?
@karlitschek does anyone of us know how to fix the database lock problems?

> @lukasreschke which bugs are you referring to that happen with sqlite? i only know the databade locking migration problems that can/show be fixed by us. totally possible.

i'm referring to the database lockings, sure they *are* fixable, but really we have much bigger problems to solve and just saying "fix it" does not solve the problem at all. if someone volunteers to fix all those database locks where we have no idea where they come from, he/she is more than welcome.

there are other big projects like [gitlabhq](https://github.com/gitlabhq/gitlabhq) that realised that sqlite is not maintainable with all those unneeded [database locks](https://github.com/gitlabhq/gitlabhq/wiki/migrate-from-sqlite-to-mysql). investing time to fix this lockup issues is just a waste of time since it is much easier to just force the user to use a proper database.

sqlite is fine for desktop applications, but it's not really the best choice for web applications. and even nearly every "wald und wiesen-hoster" is offering mysql since it is used by nearly all php applications out there. (and if he doesn't offer an appropriate db the owncloud instance will slow down anyway because of other problems)

anyways: just choosing sqlite as standard is more than ridiculous, it tells the user that he will get the best experience with this setup which is just not true. and we all know our users: 70% of them won't read the documentation or click "advanced".

(another point is the security, while most proper database setups restrict the login to "localhost" it's possible for an attacker to download the whole sqlite db once he found a vulnerability to download arbitrary files. (e.g. the recent sabredav vuln) and this is certainly not good ;-))
i think i've seen at least 10 of those database locked bugs, they were there since 4.5 (cant tell about prior versions, the ones on github are from 4.5) and no one managed to fix them.
@deepdiver1975 "jenkins is going to shut down" - this guy seems to hate me ;-)
@owncloud-bot retest this please

it is one of the main design principals of owncloud to run on as many platforms as easy as possible without admin skills. so sqlite is very important.
the lock problem appears mainly during database migration, right? so the correct behavior to check if a lock can be get from the db if not then it should try again a few times after a little wait. and if it fails again it should notify he user about the problem. the user has to make sure that there is no load at the owncloud and then try again. this should fix the issue imho, no?

> it is one of the main design principals of owncloud to run on as many platforms as easy as possible without admin skills. 

i always wondered why there are so [many outdated and insecure installations](https://gist.github.com/lukasreschke/4a3e050c19bf1b27cc8f), this is btw. just a scan of a few websites but should be kind of representative...

if you already consider that filling out 4 text fields is "too complicated" for an average user, you should check our [upgrade docs](http://doc.owncloud.org/server/5.0/admin_manual/maintenance/update.html)... 

running owncloud as a "normal user" is something you just shouldn't do. and this is just a fact.

installing and running a production mysql server is more difficult that willing in 4 text fields ;-)
running owncloud shouldn't be limited to people who can and want to run  mysql. this would shut off owncloud for most of the shared webspace users.

> running owncloud shouldn't be limited to people who can and want to run mysql. this would shut off owncloud for most of the shared webspace users.

which is btw. the intended behaviour, just check the terms of service of most of those hosting providers. i especially like all those 2.49$/month users that expect owncloud working fine and speedy in such an environment.

and really, every serious hoster is offering mysql or another database... - and as you can see on the screenshot: it's not about dropping sqlite, it's about not setting it as standard.
but if we still support sqlite then we have to fix the upgrade bug anyways, right?

> but if we still support sqlite then we have to fix the upgrade bug anyways, right? 

but not setting it as default might reduce the number of bugs related to this, plus give users a better experience with owncloud.
postgresql should be the second recommendation if available [1], and in the not so far future we should also consider mariadb.

[1] i think most bugs related to postgres have been ironed out by now @blizzz ? except the ones we reintroduce ;)

> which is btw. the intended behaviour,

i don't quite get what you mean by this @lukasreschke ?

> i don't quite get what you mean by this @lukasreschke ?

yeah - just an hint that most of our users are acting against their hosters terms of service which often forbids using it as file storage ;-)

(especially on hosters not offering a proper db ;-) )
a well hidden hint - to me at least :)

i agree with @karlitschek: â»the performance is not as good as other databases if you have a lof of users but good enough for smaller installations. so a warning here should be sufficient.â« â€“ if you run an instance with lots of users, you should damn well use mysql, but for smaller instances itâ€™s ok.

itâ€™s not about â»just filling 4 fieldsâ«. a â»databaseâ« is just a strange thing, it should just work. i would presume iâ€™m a little less technical than you folks, and i remember fiddling with a database was always a giant pain. you need to add a username, set the password  i never understood why it canâ€™t be done automatically. well it can, with sqlite.

this is not just â»changing the default from sqlite to mysqlâ«, this is complicating the installation (which is so amazingly simple currently) to a level where many people will jump off. every step in application use is like the checkout process in an online retail store â€“ and we want to enable people to get stuff as easy as possible, not overcomplicate it.

if you know your stuff, you know to use mysql anyway. for the other people it either works because they donâ€™t have that many users, they will read the notice that they maybe should switch to mysql, wherever that note is (in the installation docs probably). also, is it something specifically concerned with users or data size? maybe we can have a warning which triggers when sqlite is used and there are more than, say, 50 users (or whatever would be too much for sqlite to handle).

the problem is that the sqlite performance issue is only getting worse as we come along, as more and more stuff is running in the background the bigger the chance that a users request is being blocked by sqlite being opened by another request.

i saw at least 2 reviews of oc 5.0 that mentioned the system becoming unusually slow when an external storage was mounted. this was due to the background file scanner blocking requests because sqlite was used.

sqlite doesn't only become a problem when there are a lot of users or on a big installation, sqlite becomes a problem if there is more then one php script trying access the database, and this is getting more and more common as various kind of background jobs are introduced to improve the user experience.

i know very well why sqlite was made the default, i was one of the people who made that decision, but that was two years ago, oc has grown over the last two years, it has outgrown sqlite.

imo sqlite should still be an option, but having it as default gives people the expectation (and rightfully so) that using sqlite results in proper working oc setup in all common cases, and this is simple no longer something we can deliver without cutting back in other areas.

o.k. guys. i think we have two different issues here with sqlite and we shouldn't mix his together.

1. migration bug:
we have to support sqlite because of the discussed reasons so we have to look into this issue. an idea is to check if a full db lock can be achieved before the migration. if not then it should try it several times is over several seconds. and if it still fails then it should notify he user to reduce the load on the server and explain how to do this properly manually. the current situation is very bad because we do no error handling and leave the user with a broken installation. we have to handle this properly.

2. performance:
we have to explain to the user that the default is not recommended for bigger installations. currently we hide he other database options a bi too much imho. @jancborchardt do you have an idea how to communicate that properly and how to make the other dbs a bit more visible?

maybe instead of defaulting to one or the other the user should be presented with the two options and given a clear explanation of why to use one over the other and forced to make the decision themselves thus not having a default.  if so many are insistent on changing the default over to mysql than doing so would not add much complication anyway.  instead of having an "advanced" option which right now is only to choose the database type just have it show the two options, give the user an informed choice and let the user make that choice.

> we keep sqlite but let's add a notice on the installation that sqlite should not we used for: - syncing - external fs - more than 10 users does that make sense? 

sounds like: "well, here is our default setting sqlite, but hey you shouldn't use if you have much files or want to use a sync client or have more than one user, to be honest: you should probably never use it - but yeah it's our default configuration ;-)"

ok with keeping it, but we should change the default :-)

*i just added my comment again in order to have a better formatting*
quick side note:
i have seen a owncloud test installation with 10-15 users all running desktop clients to sync files. 

the system was almost unusable.
the apache processes used 100% cpu, sync requests timed out.

guess which db backend was used?
sqlite as it was the only option(no other db installed) and nobody(setup ui e.g.) told them that other options exist. 

to make a long story short:
they decided no to use owncloud.

my suggestion:
we keep sqlite but let's add a notice on the installation that sqlite should not we used for:
-  syncing
-  external fs
-  more than 10 users

does that make sense?
@deepdiver1975 awesome, exactly my thoughts. we should display a warning like you said imo

i agree on sqlite is a mickey mouse database and i would also appreciate to propose mysql as default. but i do not agree on blaming sqlite for too many with ownclouds database related problems. if owncloud times out with sqlite as @deepdiver1975 mentions (and it does, we have brs about that) it will do with all other databases as well, no doubt about that. just going away from sqlite as default is no solution for that. so the database code has to be analyzed and fixed all over imo. i also think that the sqlite gives us a great first usage experience so we should by no means neglect that.

if i was asked we should:
- try to detect if mysql is available on the machine, use it as default (i know that its network based...)
- otherwise use sqlite as default.
- do not neglect sqlite in any regard as it is important for the give-owncloud-a-quick-test experience.
- fix database migration and general usage.

for code how work around lock issues with sqlite, see http://git.csync.org/users/freitag/csync.git/tree/src/csync_statedb.c?h=dav, starting line 718 as example.

not offering sqlite is a simple solution for _us_, but itâ€™s a catchall solution which mainly makes onboarding incredibly harder. letâ€™s please look for a finer grained solution where we actually identify the specific problems which hape when sqlite is used, and warn in those cases.

so expanding on what i said above (â»maybe we can have a warning which triggers when sqlite is used and there are more than, say, 50 users (or whatever would be too much for sqlite to handle).â«)
we can show a warning for owncloud admins using sqlite, but _only_:
* if they have more than 10 users
* if they want to mount external storages
* some other things where sqlite is not good.

is there maybe even the possibility to offer a simple button: â»ok, i understand, letâ€™s migrate the database from sqlite to mysql, here are my credentialsâ« so they can â»upgradeâ« to mysql easily?

iâ€™m kind of adamant about the installation process staying as simple as it is now. we should definitely not force people to make a database decision (@tekati), because owncloud should not just be installable by people who know what a database is.
@farson2003 yes, unless you dont upload any files and dont sync

@raydiation i think you spread fud against sqlite here ;-) better check out https://github.com/owncloud/mirall/issues/331#issuecomment-15032047 if 600 requests per put is true, we should do our homework first and bring that down to a reasonable number per put (which, from my gut feeling, should be below 20) and than again think about sqlite's pros and cons.

i agree with @dragotin it's no the faul of sqlite that our exception handling during upgrades is broken. we have to fix that. and if one single user is creating too much load for an sqlite instance then we have clearly somehing to optimize in owncloud. so guys. please don't spread fud and let's search for the error on our side.

ok - i've thought about that what our old wise man ;-) @dragotin said. and have to agree with him.

@karlitschek i'd appreciate it if we would have something like a "database task force" which is mainly working on database issues, we have this bugs since 4.5 or so and we should certainly have some guys fixing this ;-)
sure, we need to fix those issues but sqlite in oc will never be more stable than mysql, thats why it shouldnt be the default. the default should be the db which offers the best experience
